column85: I don't know the criteria supposed to be used to select csp in neurofeedback, so I imagined! Presence of a high contrast in the csp (hope it may maximise sensitivity), lateralized pattern (cerebral activity expected controlateral to the imagined moving hand), pattern similar to the left figure entitled "hand" (hypothesis that the imagined activity is similar to the one evoked by a real hand movement)

column83: Clear choice (one CSP clearly stood out)
column85:
I selected the CSP filters that captured physiologically plausible patterns reflected in alpha–beta power modulations. When no clearly defined spatial pattern emerged in the power plot, I selected the filter that best reflected the expected right-hand motor imagery pattern, namely a lateralized difference over the left sensorimotor cortex. I also aimed to avoid filters showing a strong influence of artifacts.
If you use you use mne.decoding.CSP, it would be interesting to know which parameter you use for component_order (‘mutual_info’ or ‘alternate’). This information would help to clarify which class/task variance each filter is maximizing or minimizing, and therefore have a better interpretation of the physiological patterns reflected by the selected components.

column83: Clear choice (one CSP clearly stood out)
column85: Since the task involved motor imagination, I initially selected the motor area, and since we know it's the right hand, I then prioritized the left hemisphere. Furthermore, I avoided selecting regions most susceptible to physiological artifacts: blinking, swallowing, head movement, and visual stimulation.

column83: Clear choice (one CSP clearly stood out)
column85:
To select the CSP, I focused on the different activation patterns that were shown in the 1rst image on the left. I tried to select the one that matches most the original pattern. I was also interested in the "power" of the activation and that was a criteria of choice of the CSP I believe was right. 
I also tried to remember where I was supposed to see an activation with this type of task, but I find it quite hard to choose, specifically when no distinct pattern emerged on the different CSP. Also, I supposed that the major pre-frontal activation that was on the different CSP was blinks, but maybe I was wrong. 
To sum up, I'm not familiar with neurofeedback and I think this task was hard and I was not very confident in my different choices.

column84: For right vs rest, the choice is clear but some subjects also have activations in the ipsilateral hemisphere (in addition to contrallateral) so B might have worked too
column85: Event related desynchronization in beta usually appear in the opposite side as the one imagined so strong left-sided activations are a must for this kind of CSP. In the right vs rest paradigm, it is also possible to choose right-sided activations as they can sometimes appear too and might not be related to left motor imagery in this case. In any case, when there is a strong activation in the surroundings of the EEG, it is usually eye movements or muscular artefacts.

column85: First off, I have not carried out MI-BCI research myself so far, but I have worked with CSPs (albeit I used a a fixed number of CSPs selected automatically after sorting eigenvalues). My strategy for this task was to look for pattern that either mimicked the topoplot on the left in a good way or matched what I have seen left/right hand CSPs in articles before (with a lateralized difference somewhat closely positioned to C3 or C4.

column85: As I am unfamiliar with using CSP in my neurofeedback / BCI studies protocoles, I tried superposing the ERD map with the proposed CSP maps.
